At-a-Glance: Feed only when necessary: thin syrup (1:1) to stimulate spring build-up, thick syrup (2:1) or fondant to prevent starvation in autumn/winter, protein patties when pollen is genuinely scarce and brood rearing is desired.
Why it Matters: Sugar is not a perfect substitute for nectar and pollen; misuse drives poor comb use or ill-timed brood rearing.
Step-by-Step: Assess stores and natural flows first. Use internal feeders to reduce robbing. Stop stimulative feeding ahead of winter bee rearing; avoid unknown/contaminated honey.
Common Pitfalls: Over-feeding during strong flows, relying on HFCS of uncertain quality, or feeding protein when colonies are broodless.
Tools & Materials: Reliable feeders, refractometer for honey moisture checks, accurate scales/logs for tracking consumption.
